addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

13 Sep
t
1592.
M
r
Bodeley. to my L. from
e Haghe

page.lettertext:
fol.233r
May it please yo
r
good L. Having moved
the states to
e effect of
at letter, w
ch
I had
last from her
Ma
tie
to be contented to licence
one Englishe horseband, to accompany
e foote-
men
at are going for
France,
I could obtene
no other answear, nor I expected no other,
then
at w
ch
was made to my last proposition,
w
ch
I sent unto yo
r
L.
e 6 of this moneth,
That it was directly against her Ma
ties
Treaty.
Unto w
ch
allegation I would not enter to replie,
knowing nothing will prevaile, to purchase
their good liking of w
t
drawing
e companies.
Howbeit I signified plainely to them,
at there
was never no Contract, so wrested from
e pur-
pose,
at was first intended by
e parties, as
at
had bin by them: as if her Ma
tie
were minded
to charge
e state in
at behalf, it would be decla-
red in very many pointes. In
e meane season,
to
e end they might not so easely, if they were
bent therunto, impeache
e comming from
e Campe
of
e forsaid horseband, almost two daies before,
I sent away my letters to
S
r
Nicholas Parker
, kno-
wing none of
e troupes in better state to be im-
ploied in
at service then his: and himself to be
somwhat skilled in
e Frenche tongue, for w
ch
I
thought him
e rather to be fitte for
at voiage.
Moreover because I doubt lest
e states
companies, w
ch
are to
goe
come
in their places,
at goe
out of
Berghen,
will not be found to be so ready,
as will be requisit, I have requested them againe
in their publicke meeting, to send their troupes
thither in convenient season, lest
e towne should
fol.233v
be disfournished, and inconvenience growe upon
it, wherof
e fault should rest in them.
I have also wished
S
r
Thomas Morgan
, because
e
place is committed by
e contrey to his charge, to
require it to be done by some letters from himself,
geving warning unto them,
at if their compa-
nies doe not come, when
e rest doe embarke,
that they must hold him excused, for any dan-
ger
at shall happen. Howe
e states
will resolve for
e imploiment of their forces
between this and
e winter, it is not yet know
e
.
Their armie still remaineth in
e quarters of
Coe-
voerden
, and will not remove, till ether the
Enemie be passed
e Rhine, wherof there is speeche
at this very instant, or
e Castel of Coevoer-
en sufficiently fortified, w
ch
is thought w
t
in
this sevenight will be done very thorowly:
e
multitude of labourers are so many about it.
I hope
at this day or to morowe,
e companies
of
S
r
Francis Vere
will be at
Roterodam
or
Dort,
and then they will be ready for
e first
winde.
And thus I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Sep
t
13 1592
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
